response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "The purpose of this Act is to permanently establish the women's court program in the first circuit. [CHUNK_6] It also establishes a two-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [CHUNK_6] The bill also requires the judiciary to submit reports to the legislature regarding the pilot program for women's court. [CHUNK_8]",
  "appropriations": "There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $514,900 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_20] These funds are for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services and equipment, and the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position. [CHUNK_20, CHUNK_21] The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary for the purposes of this Act. [CHUNK_21]",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The provided documents do not detail the specific methodology used to calculate the appropriation amounts for the pilot program. [CHUNK_20] The program's goals are to divert participants from incarceration, support their success in the community, and reduce recidivism by implementing trauma-informed and evidence-based practices. [CHUNK_13] The cost assumptions are based on providing services that address trauma and mental health treatment, family support, life-skills training, vocational training, substance abuse treatment, and housing support. [CHUNK_14, CHUNK_15]",
  "agency_impact": "The judiciary is responsible for establishing the permanent women's court program in the first circuit. [CHUNK_9] It must also establish the women's court pilot program within the third circuit Kona division, which will be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [CHUNK_12] The judiciary is also responsible for providing mental health services under the pilot program and submitting reports to the legislature on its findings and recommendations in 2026 and 2027. [CHUNK_12, CHUNK_16]",
  "economic_impact": "The legislature finds that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. [CHUNK_2] The program aims to reduce recidivism and divert participants from incarceration, which may lead to long-term cost savings for the state. [CHUNK_10] By addressing unique barriers women offenders face, such as being primary caregivers and lacking stable work history, the program can help them achieve more positive outcomes and economic stability. [CHUNK_3]",
  "policy_impact": "This measure permanently establishes the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit by codifying it in the Hawaii Revised Statutes. [CHUNK_30] It also establishes a temporary two-year Women's Court Pilot Program within the Kona division of the Third Circuit. [CHUNK_23] This represents a change from a previous version of the bill, which proposed a three-year pilot program. [CHUNK_31]",
  "revenue_sources": "The program is funded by an appropriation out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_19] The measure appropriates the sum of $514,900 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026. [CHUNK_20] An additional $557,000 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) is appropriated from general revenues for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_20]",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The measure appropriates $514,900 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) in FY 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) in FY 2026-2027 from the general fund for the Kona pilot program. [CHUNK_20] The pilot program and its associated funding are set to be repealed on June 30, 2027. [CHUNK_22] The appropriation covers mental health and substance abuse treatment, other services, equipment, and one temporary (1.0 FTE) Kona drug court probation supervisor position. [CHUNK_20, CHUNK_21] Making the First Circuit women's court program permanent creates an ongoing fiscal obligation, though no specific funds are appropriated for that purpose in this Act. [CHUNK_6] The Judiciary must submit reports on the pilot program prior to the 2026 and 2027 legislative sessions. [CHUNK_16] These reports will include recommendations as to whether the pilot program should continue, expand, provide additional services, or be discontinued. [CHUNK_19] The findings in these reports will inform future fiscal decisions. [CHUNK_16]",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The provided legislative documents do not indicate any anticipated impact on operating revenues resulting from this measure.",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The provided legislative documents do not specify any major capital expenditures. [CHUNK_20] The appropriation includes funding for \"equipment\" for the women's court pilot program. [CHUNK_20] No funds are allocated for facilities or other significant capital investments. [CHUNK_20]",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "Part III of the Act, which establishes the women's court pilot program in the Kona division, will be repealed on June 30, 2027, ending the fiscal obligations for that specific program. [CHUNK_22] However, the measure makes the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit permanent. [CHUNK_6] This will result in ongoing fiscal implications beyond the six-year period to sustain the First Circuit program, though the associated costs are not specified in this measure. [CHUNK_9]",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "This version of the bill restores specific appropriation amounts, which were previously unspecified; the pilot program's duration is reduced from three years to two. [CHUNK_31, CHUNK_32] The number of temporary FTE positions is reduced from two to one, with only the Kona drug court probation supervisor position remaining. [CHUNK_32] A requirement for the Judiciary to report on the need for pilot programs in other circuits has been deleted. [CHUNK_33] The sunset date for the Kona pilot program has been moved from 2028 to June 30, 2027, and the defective effective date has been corrected to July 1, 2025. [CHUNK_34, CHUNK_35]",
  "fte_positions": "The measure appropriates funds for the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position. [CHUNK_21] This is a change from a previous version of the bill that had authorized two temporary positions. [CHUNK_32] The second position, a peer specialist, is no longer included in the measure. [CHUNK_21]",
  "appropriations_changes": "This version of the bill has been amended to include specific appropriation amounts, which were unspecified in the prior version. [CHUNK_32] The measure appropriates $514,900 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [CHUNK_32] The purpose of the appropriation is for services, equipment, and one temporary position for the Kona pilot program. [CHUNK_32]",
  "funding_sources_changes": "The method of funding remains the general revenues of the State of Hawaii. [CHUNK_19] The significant change from the previous version is that the appropriation amounts from the general fund are now specified. [CHUNK_32] There are no other changes to the funding source. [CHUNK_19]",
  "department_impact": "The sums appropriated shall be expended by the judiciary. [CHUNK_21] There are no changes to the department responsible for expending the funds compared to the previous fiscal note. [CHUNK_21] The Judiciary is responsible for implementing the permanent program and the pilot program. [CHUNK_9, CHUNK_12]",
  "reports_required": "This version deletes the language that would have required the Judiciary to submit a report regarding the need for a pilot program in the Second and Fifth Circuits and Hilo division of the Third Circuit. [CHUNK_33] The judiciary is still required to submit a report of its findings and recommendations on the Kona pilot program to the governor and legislature before the regular sessions of 2026 and 2027. [CHUNK_16] This report must include recommendations on whether the pilot program should continue, expand, or be discontinued. [CHUNK_19]",
  "pilot_program": "The conference committee has amended this measure by changing the duration of the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit from three years to two years. [CHUNK_31, CHUNK_32] The bill continues to make the women's court program in the first circuit permanent. [CHUNK_6] The women's court pilot program shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [CHUNK_12]",
  "sunset_date": "The sunset date for the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit has been changed to June 30, 2027. [CHUNK_35] Part III of this Act, which establishes the pilot program, shall be repealed on this date. [CHUNK_22]",
  "effective_date": "The effective date for the Act has been changed to July 1, 2025. [CHUNK_34] This corrects a defective effective date from a previous version of the measure. [CHUNK_34]"
}

OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that there has been a significant increase in the number of women in Hawai ʻ i jails and prisons over the past forty years, resulting in a higher proportion of women who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of

who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. Women offenders also face unique barriers to success after incarceration. They are more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have

more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience economic or social marginalization, which prevents them from having more positive outcomes. The legislature further finds that Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program

of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the first circuit. This program, known as Mohala Wahine, focuses on non-violent women who are at high risk of recidivism and in need of multiple services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The

services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began accepting participants in January 2023, with a goal of admitting twenty women each year. As of August 2024, twenty-three women are currently participating in the program, with eleven participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in

participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. The purpose of this Act is to: (1) Permanently establish the women's court program in the first circuit; (2) Establish a two-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the

in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs; and (3) Require the judiciary to submit reports to the legislature regarding the pilot program for women's

reports to the legislature regarding the pilot program for women's court. PART II SECTION 2. (a) There shall be established within the

program; first circuit. (a) There shall be established within the first circuit of the judiciary the women's court program. of this bill in an amended form. The purpose of this measure is to (1) Make the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent; (2) Establish and appropriate funds for a three-year Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit; and (3) Require the

overview.prompt: Using the provided legislative documents, statutes, and testimonies, write a clear summary describing the purpose, scope, and key components of the proposed measure or bill, including any pilot or permanent programs, reporting requirements, and sunset clauses. This should be around 3 sentences.
overview.description: General overview and summary of the measure

appropriations.prompt: Based on budgetary data and legislative appropriations, detail the funding allocated for the program or measure, including fiscal years, amounts, intended uses such as staffing, training, contracts, technology, etc... This should be around 3 sentences.

assumptions_and_methodology.prompt: Explain the assumptions, cost estimation methods, and data sources used to calculate the financial projections for this program or measure, referencing comparable programs or historical budgets where applicable. This should be around 3 sentences.

agency_impact.prompt: Describe the anticipated operational, administrative, and budgetary impact of the program or measure on the relevant government agency or department, including supervision, staffing, and resource allocation. This should be around 3 sentences.
agency_impact.description: Impact on government agencies and departments

economic_impact.prompt: Summarize the expected economic effects of the program or measure, such as cost savings, potential reductions in related expenditures, benefits to the community, and any relevant performance or participation statistics. This should be around 3 sentences.

policy_impact.prompt: Analyze the policy implications of the measure, including how it modifies existing laws or programs, its role within broader legislative strategies, and its potential effects on state or local governance. This should be around 3 sentences.

revenue_sources.prompt: Identify and describe the funding sources that will support the program or measure, such as general funds, grants, fees, or other revenue streams, based on the provided fiscal documents. This should be around 3 sentences.

six_year_fiscal_implications.prompt: Provide a multi-year fiscal outlook (e.g., six years) for the program or measure, projecting costs, staffing changes, recurring expenses, and assumptions about program expansion or permanence using available budget and workload data. This should be around 10 sentences.

operating_revenue_impact.prompt: Describe any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from the program or measure, including increases, decreases, or changes in revenue streams. This should be around 3 sentences.

capital_expenditure_impact.prompt: Outline any expected capital expenditures related to the program or measure, such as investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure, based on capital budgets or agency plans. This should be around 3 sentences.

fiscal_implications_after_6_years.prompt: Summarize the ongoing fiscal obligations after the initial multi-year period for the program or measure, including annual operating costs, expected number of program sites or units, and the sustainability of funding. This should be around 3 sentences.
fiscal_implications_after_6_years.description: Long-term fiscal obligations beyond six years

updates_from_previous_fiscal_note.prompt: If you are given a previous fiscal note. Please summarize the MAIN POINTS that are different from the previous fiscal note and the new fiscal note.

fte_positions.prompt: Detail any Full Time Equivalent (FTE) positions that have been added or modified in this version of the bill, including the number of positions, their roles, and any changes from previous versions. This should be around 3 sentences.

appropriations_changes.prompt: Identify and describe any appropriations that were previously unspecified or have been modified between versions of the bill, including the amounts and purposes of the appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
appropriations_changes.description: Changes to appropriations between bill versions

funding_sources_changes.prompt: Specify the method of funding (MOF) for appropriations and identify any changes in funding sources between versions, such as shifts between general fund and special fund appropriations. This should be around 3 sentences.
funding_sources_changes.description: Changes to funding sources and method of funding

department_impact.prompt: Describe any changes in which department is responsible for expending appropriations, including shifts from one department to another between bill versions (e.g., from Department of Health to Judiciary). This should be around 3 sentences.
department_impact.description: Changes in department responsibility for appropriations

reports_required.prompt: Identify any reports that agencies are required to submit to the legislature, including new reporting requirements or modifications to existing ones. This should be around 3 sentences.

pilot_program.prompt: If the bill creates a pilot program, describe the length of the pilot program and whether it was initially intended to be a pilot program or a permanent program. This should be around 3 sentences.

sunset_date.prompt: Identify the sunset date for the bill or program, including any modifications to the sunset date between versions. This should be around 2 sentences.

effective_date.prompt: Identify the effective date of the bill, noting if there was a defective effective date in a previous version and what the corrected effective date is. This should be around 2 sentences.

OF HAWAII: PART I SECTION 1. The legislature finds that there has been a significant increase in the number of women in Hawai ʻ i jails and prisons over the past forty years, resulting in a higher proportion of women who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of

who are incarcerated. Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. Women offenders also face unique barriers to success after incarceration. They are more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have

more likely to be primary caregivers for young children, have lower educational attainment, lack stable work history, and experience economic or social marginalization, which prevents them from having more positive outcomes. The legislature further finds that Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program

of Hawaii 2022, established a three-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the first circuit. This program, known as Mohala Wahine, focuses on non-violent women who are at high risk of recidivism and in need of multiple services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The

services such as substance abuse treatment, therapy, or housing. The program began accepting participants in January 2023, with a goal of admitting twenty women each year.
